Lillie_Mae:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Lillie Mae | landscape = | alt = From the album Forever and Then Some - 2017 | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = Lillie Mae Rische | alias = | birth_date = | birth_place =[[Galena, Illinois]], U.S. | origin = | death_date = | death_place = | genre = [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[country music|country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] | occupation = | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[fiddle]] | years_active = 2013-present | label = [[Third Man Records]] | website = {{URL|https://www.lilliemaemusic.com/}} |past_member_of = [[Jypsi]] }} '''Lillie Mae''' (born '''Lillie Mae Rische''' on June 26, 1991) is an American [[Country music|country]] and [[Americana (music)|Americana]] singer, songwriter, fiddle and guitar player based in [[Nashville]], Tennessee.{{cite web|last1=Hight|first1=Jewly|title=World Cafe Nashville: Lillie Mae|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/world-cafe/2017/06/30/529708788/world-cafe-nashville-lillie-mae|publisher=[[NPR Music]]|accessdate=24 August 2017}} ==Career== === Early career === Lillie Mae Rische{{Cite web|url=https://www.theeastnashvillian.com/lillie-mae-no-other-girl/|title=No Other Girl|last=Randy Fox|date=2019-07-16|website=The East Nashvillian|language=en-US|access-date=2019-08-20}} started playing and performing live at the age of 3. She started playing guitar at age 4 and started playing fiddle at age 7. Lillie Mae and her family toured as a family band for many years. Her father, Forrest Carter, left when she was 11. The family settled in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] in 2000. Her family began playing the local [[Honky-tonk|honky tonks]] (Laylas) with her siblings, Frank, Scarlett, Amber-Dawn and McKenna Grace, as [[Jypsi]]. Most of the siblings signed with [[Arista Records]] in 2007 and had two Top 40 singles on [[Hot Country Songs]] the next year "I Don't Love You Like That".{{Cite web|url=https://theboot.com/who-is-lillie-mae/|title=Who Is Lillie Mae? 5 Things You Need to Know|first=Riane|last=Konc|website=Theboot.com|date=21 March 2018 |accessdate=August 16, 2019}} === Third Man Records and Jack White === Mae began doing [[Session musician|session work]] for [[Third Man Records]], which led to her playing fiddle on [[Jack White|Jack White's]] 2012 (Blunderbuss) and 2014 (Lazaretto) tours. She was part of the female band that toured alongside the male band. In 2013, Lillie Mae appeared in several spots in the filmed concert ''Another Day, Another Time: Celebrating the Music of Inside Llewyn Davis''.{{cite web|title=Another Day, Another Time: Celebrating the Music of Inside Llewyn Davis|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3358552/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast|website=[[IMDb]]|accessdate=11 Mar 2018}} She sang and played violin on "Did You Hear John Hurt?" and "We're Going to Be Friends" alongside Jack White.{{cite web|title=Jack White - Did You Hear John Hurt? / We're Going to Be Friends |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UyFYprY-H4k|website=[[YouTube]]| date=30 June 2014 |accessdate=11 Mar 2018}} Mae has appeared on all three of [[Jack White discography#Studio albums|Jack White's solo records]], as well as on [[The Raconteurs|The Raconteurs']] 2019 album ''[[Help Us Stranger]]''. === Solo career === In 2014, Mae released her first solo song titled "Nobody's".{{cite web|last1=Lewis|first1=Randy|title=Premiere: Jack White band singer-fiddler Lillie Mae Rische's 'Nobody's'|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-lillie-mae-rische-jack-white-band-nobodys-20141216-htmlstory.html|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=17 December 2014 |accessdate=24 August 2017}} In 2015 she released ''Rain On The Piano''. On June 23, 2017, Lillie Mae released ''Forever and Then Some'' on Third Man Records.{{cite web|title=25 Best Country and Americana Albums of 2017 So Far|date=5 July 2017 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/lists/25-best-country-and-americana-albums-of-2017-so-far-w490843/lillie-mae-forever-and-then-some-w490859|publisher=[[Rolling Stone]]|accessdate=24 August 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Cooper|first1=Leonie|title=Lillie Mae – 'Forever and Then Some' Review|date=21 June 2017 |url=https://www.nme.com/reviews/album/lillie-mae-forever-and-then-some-review|publisher=[[NME]]|accessdate=24 August 2017}} The album was produced by Jack White and featured contributions from her siblings, Frank and Scarlett and McKenna Grace.{{cite web|last1=Rettig|first1=James|title=Jack White Producing Debut Solo Album From His Touring Band's Fiddler Lillie Mae Rische|date=14 October 2016 |url=https://www.stereogum.com/1905174/jack-white-producing-debut-solo-album-from-his-touring-bands-fiddler-lillie-mae-rische/news/|publisher=[[Stereogum]]|accessdate=24 August 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Shelter|first1=Carter|title=Meet Lillie Mae With Her Jack White-Produced New Single "Over The Hill and Through The Woods"|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2017/02/meet-lillie-mae-with-her-jack-white-produced-new-s.html|publisher=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|accessdate=24 August 2017}} In 2017, she performed in the multi-award-winning documentary ''[[The American Epic Sessions]]''. In this musical feature, she played both fiddle and [[mandolin]] alongside Jack White, [[Jack White|Dominic Davis]], and [[Fats Kaplin]] as part of the backing band for artists such as [[Willie Nelson]] and [[Merle Haggard]], [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]], [[Steve Martin]] and [[Edie Brickell]], and [[Ana Gabriel]]. Merle Haggard played her fiddle on the show. She played fiddle and provided background vocals on [[Jim Lauderdale]]'s 2018 album ''Time Flies''. On August 16, 2019, Lillie Mae released her follow up studio album, ''Other Girls'' on Third Man Records.{{Cite web|url=https://thirdmanstore.com/other-girls|title=Lillie Mae {{!}} Other Girls LP or CD|website=thirdmanstore.com|access-date=2019-08-20}} It was produced by the [[Dave Cobb]] and recorded at Nashville's [[RCA Studio A]]. Lillie Mae has performed as a solo artist on both ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'' and ''[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]].{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/watch-lillie-maes-scorching-solo-debut-on-conan-w476857|title=Watch Lillie Mae's Scorching Solo Debut on 'Conan'|last1=Gold|first1=Adam|date=14 April 2017 |publisher=Rolling Stone|accessdate=24 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/lillie-mae-on-colbert-see-over-the-hill-w490164|title=See Lillie Mae's Hypnotic 'Over the Hill and Through the Woods' on 'Colbert'|last1=Gage|first1=Jeff|date=28 June 2017 |publisher=Rolling Stone}}'' She toured with [[Robert Plant|Robert Plant's]] [[Robert Plant#Sensational Space Shifters (2012–2018)|Sensational Space Shifters]], opening most shows acoustically with her partner Misael Arriaga. Arriaga also plays in Lillie Mae's touring band. Lillie Mae plays with her siblings still in the family band, (The Risches) and plays downtown Nashville at Layla's whenever she is not touring. ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:12em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:17em;"| Album details ! colspan="3"| Peak chart positions ! rowspan="2" style="width:9em;"| Sales |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! style="width:4em;"| US
